<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 309, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 325, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 571, 94]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 2\tan x - 5\sin x\) for \(0\leqslant x< \frac{1}{2}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the stationary point of the curve. Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 452, 93]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(x^{2}\ln y + y^{2} + 4x = 9.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 470, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point (2, 1).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 698, 94]]<|/det|>
Sketch on the same diagram the graphs of \(y = \left|3x - 8\right|\) and \(y = 5 - x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 600, 146, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 600, 448, 618]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(\left|3x - 8\right| < 5 - x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 82, 96, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 75, 740, 107]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{1 + \mathrm{e}^{2x}}{1 + 3x}\). The curve has exactly one stationary point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 146, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 121, 841, 149]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) and hence show that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) satisfies the equation \(x = \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{2}\mathrm{e}^{-2x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 128, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 740, 88]]<|/det|>
Show by calculation that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) lies between 0.35 and 0.45 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 176, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 504, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula based on the equation in part (a) to find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) correct to 3 significant figures. Give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 83, 650, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 262, 920, 311]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = \sqrt{\sin 2x + \sin^2 2x}\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{6}\pi\). The shaded region is bounded by the curve and the straight lines \(x = \frac{1}{6}\pi\) and \(y = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 322, 144, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 322, 920, 356]]<|/det|>
Use the trapezium rule with two intervals to find an approximation to the area of the shaded region. Give your answer correct to 2 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
